Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Continuation of Development and Application of AO-FVCOM to Improve Understanding of Arctic Changes
Award.AbstractNarration:
The PIs have successfully developed a high-resolution unstructured-grid, finitevolume
coupled ice-ocean model for the Arctic Ocean (AO-FVCOM). AO-FVCOM has been
validated via comparison to observed data under climatological conditions. Now they seek support to work on the following three tasks:
1) Calibrate and validate AO-FVCOM using observational data collected in the Canada Arctic Basin and its marginal Chukchi and Beaufort Sea. This region is chosen for intense study because it has the most pronounced loss of sea ice extent and thickness in recent years and its unprecedented coverage by multiyear national and international field and modeling studies.
2) Apply the new calibrated and validated AV-FVCOM to investigate the following scientific topics:
a) improve understanding of the circulation of the Alaskan Coastal Current and Pacific and Atlantic waters in the study region,
b) revisit scientific questions and methodological problems associated with shelf-basin exchange (SBE) processes in the region, and
c) apply AO-FVCOM to investigate transformations and transports of fresh water (both liquid and solid) from freshwater sources (Bering Strait, rivers, central Beaufort Gyre, precipitation) towards the North Atlantic Ocean via Fram and Canadian Archipelago Straits.
3) Train a Ph.D. student in advanced Arctic Ocean modeling.

Successful completion of this project will provide an additional protocol for modeling Arctic Ocean processes. It will also advance understanding of the circulation and mixing processes in the Arctic Ocean, processes which will grow in socio-economic importance with increasing ice loss and development activities in this part of the globe.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The high-resolution (up to 2 km), unstructured-grid, fully coupled Arctic sea ice-ocean Finite-Volume Community Ocean Model (AO-FVCOM) was employed to study the seasonal and interannual variability of water circulation and sea ice drift in the Arctic Ocean over the period 1978-2014. A set of numerical experiments was conducted to investigate model’s sensitivity to external forcing, parameterizations of wind-ice and ice-ocean stresses, grid resolution and other internal model parameters. Special attention was paid to the investigation of water circulation, hydrographic conditions and ice characteristics in the Canadian Arctic Archipelago (CAA) Straits under influence of local and regional atmospheric forcing. The simulated Canadian Arctic Archipelago (CAA) through water flow was in reasonable agreement with observation across Davis Strait, Nares Strait, Lancaster Sound and Jones Sounds and highly correlated with the along-strait and cross-strait sea surface height gradients. It was found that regional (over the Canada Basin) sea level pressure  and winds play an important role in the water fluxes through CAA. Project results were broadly disseminated to the general oceanographic community, undergraduate and graduate education communities and to the public through websites of UMASSD and WHOI. For example, results of this study were presented at AOMIP and FAMOS meetings where major project accomplishments were discussed by both modelers and observersOne PhD student was advised and trained at the University of Massachussets Darthmouth and three manuscripts were published in peer-reviewed journals.
